docs.text: Zendikit School Education is an investment in the betterment of the present and future of the human condition. We take no money from you, and in return we confer no degree. We are interested only in growing skills backed by deep understanding. All material is project-based where practical. Participation requires that you are self-directed, have a computer, and have internet access.

docs.text: Introduction The purpose of this catalog is to bootstrap reading ability to expedite consuming Japanese material. This catalog is not exhaustive. There is grammar in the Japanese language not present here. Also, for grammar points presented here, there are nuances not covered. While certification such as that provided by the JLPT is not indicative of language mastery, the various JLPT levels do provide a convenient way to organize practical grammar points. Here we provide a catalog of grammar by approximate JLPT level. Grammar points in each level are presented in alphabetical order . Prerequisites You must know the kana. Also, while we try to use relatively simple vocabulary in the example sentences, you should understand the general-use kanji --if not the readings then at least the meanings to intuit the gist of the example sentences. References We recommend A Dictionary of Basic Japanese Grammar , A Dictionary of Intermediate Japanese Grammar , and A Dictionary of Advanced Japanese Grammar , all by Makino and Tsutsui, as supplements.

docs.text: N5 Grammar か Grammar Point Sentence 1 私は英語 か 日本語を勉強します。 I will study either English or Japanese. 明日授業がある か ない か 分かりません。 I don't know whether there is class tomorrow or not. A grammar particle which indicates an alternative. から Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本へ行く から 日本語を勉強する。 I'm studying Japanese because I'm going to Japan next year. 高かった から 買いませんでした。 I didn't buy it because it was expensive. 2 日本語を勉強して から 全部を忘れました。 After studying Japanese, I forgot everything. A conjunction indicating a reason or cause. A conjunction indicating after or since something takes place. くらい Grammar Point Sentence 1 百五十円 くらい でした。 It was about 150 yen. 二時間 くらい かかります。 I takes about 2 hours. A particle indicating an approximate quantity or otherwise translated as "about." ぐらい has the same meaning. しか Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語 しか 勉強しません。 I study only Japanese. A particle indicating that something S and only S is the case, often translated as "nothing," "nobody," or "only." すぐ Grammar Point Sentence 1 朝起きて すぐ に日本語を勉強します。 As soon as I wake up, I study Japanese. 学校は駅の すぐ 前です。 The school is right in front of the station. An adverb indicating not much temporal or physical distance, often translated as "as soon as," "immediately," "right." たい Grammar Point Sentence 1 私は日本語を勉強し たい です。 I want to study Japanese. 私は刺身を食べ たい です。 I i want to eat sashimi. An auxiliary adjective indicating the desire to do something. だけ Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語が勉強した だけ です。 I just studied (and did nothing else with) Japanese. 私 だけ 日本語を話せます。 Only I can speak Japanese. A particle expressing a limit on something, often translated as "just," "merely," "only," or "that's all." だろう See でしょう. て Grammar Point Sentence 1 私は日本へ行っ て 勉強しました。 I went to Japan and studied. これは高く て 美味しい。 This is expensive and delicious. 彼は先生 で 優しい。 He is a teacher, and he is nice. A verb or i-adjective ending indicating "and." For na-adjectives and nouns, て becomes で instead. で Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本人ははし で 食べます。 Japanese people eat with chopsticks. これは日本語 で 何ですか。 What is this in Japanese? A grammar particle which indicates the use of something for doing something. でしょう Grammar Point Sentence 1 彼は日本語で話す でしょう 。 He will probably speak in Japanese. この本は高い だろう 。 This book is probably expensive. An auxiliary indicating conjecture grounded in no substantial evidence. だろう is the informal form. でも Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語 でも 話せます。 I can even speak Japanese. 子供 でも そのことをできます。 Even a child can do that. A particle meaning "even." と Grammar Point Sentence 1 私はあなた と 日本語を勉強します。 I study Japanese with you. 私は日本人 と 結婚しました。 I (got) married ( to ) a Japanese person. A grammar particle indicating a reciprocal relationship with the subject. どう Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語で どう 言いますか。 How do you say it in Japanese? 本は どう でしたか。 How was the book? A grammar particle which asks about the state of something or someone or the way of doing something. と同じくらい〜 Grammar Point Sentence 1 この本はその本 と同じくらい 面白い。 This book is as interesting as that one. A phrase indicating that one thing is as 〜 as another. どちら Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語と英語と、 どちら が面白い？ Between Japanese and English, which is more interesting? A word meaning "which," among a group of things, particularly two. どれ Grammar Point Sentence 1 黄色と紫色と青色で、 どれ が一番美しいですか。 Between yellow, purple, and blue, which is the most beautiful? A word meaning "which," among a group of 3 or more. ないで Grammar Point Sentence 1 勉強し ないで 学校へ来ました。 I came to school without studying. A negative te-form indicating not doing something or without doing something. ながら Grammar Point Sentence 1 本を読み ながら 学校へ歩きました。 I walked to school while reading a book. A conjunction indicating the surrounding clauses happen simultaneously, often translated as "while" or "with." に Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語を勉強（し） に 学校へ行きます。 I'm going to school (in order) to study Japanese. 本を買い に 来ました。 I came (in order) to buy a book. A particle indicating the purpose of movement. This construct is only used with motion verbs like 行く, 来る, 帰る, 入る, and 出る. の Grammar Point Sentence 1 本は日本語 の を買いました。 As for books, I bought a Japanese one . あの本はトム の です。 That book is Tom's book . 2 どうして勉強している の ？ Why are you studying ( you've got to tell me )? 明日テストがある の 。 Because there's a test tomorrow. A dependent, indefinite pronoun indicating "one" or "_'s." An informal sentence-final particle indicating an explanation or asking for an explanation, used by children or female speakers. If male speakers use it, it is only for questions. のです Grammar Point Sentence 1 何をしている んです か。 What are you doing ( you've got to tell me )? 日本語を勉強している のです 。 ( The explanation is that ) I'm studying Japanese. A sentence-ending phrase indicating an explanation or asking for an explanation. An informal form is んです. ばかり Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語 ばかり 勉強しています。 I'm studying only Japanese. 私は勉強した ばかり です。 I studied and haven't done anything else . A particle indicating that something is the only state, thing, or action. ほう Grammar Point Sentence 1 あなたの本はどっちですか。 Which book is yours? 大きい ほう です。 The bigger one. 好きな ほう を取ってください。 Please take the one you like most . A word indicating more than or greater in a comparison. It comes from the form ほうが〜より. ほうが〜より Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語の ほうが 英語 より 面白い。 Japanese is more interesting than English. 遊ぶ ほうが 勉強する より 楽しい。 Playing is more fun than studying. A phrase for comparing two things, where one is more or greater than the other. ほど Grammar Point Sentence 1 英語は日本語 ほど 面白くない。 English is not as interesting as Japanese. A particle indicating an extent or degree, often translated as "[not] as ~ as ~." 〜ましょう Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語を勉強し ましょう 。 Let's study Japanese. 日本語を勉強し ましょう か。 Shall we study Japanese? A formal volitional verb ending indicating the speaker's intent or invitation to do something. 〜ませんか Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語を勉強し ませんか 。 Would you like to study Japanese? 2 一緒に勉強し ない？ Wanna study together? The formal negative question form of a verb can be used to extend an invitation formally. The informal non-past negative form of a verb can be used to extend an invitation informally. まで Grammar Point Sentence 1 私は五時 まで 日本語を勉強します。 I will study Japanese until 5 o'clock. 東京 まで 3時間かかります。 It takes 3 hours until Tokyo. A grammar particle which indicates a spacial or temporal limit. よう Grammar Point Sentence 1 日本語を勉強し よう 。 Let's study Japanese. 地球を守 ろう 。 Let's protect the Earth. An informal volition verb ending indicating the speaker's intent or invitation to do something. られる Grammar Point Sentence 1 漢字を読 める 。 I can read kanji. 刺身を食べ られます 。 I can eat sashimi. An auxiliary verb indicating the potential to do something. を Grammar Point Sentence 1 私は日本語 を 勉強します。 I study Japanese. 2 私は公園 を 歩きました。 I walked through the park. A grammar particle indicating a direct object. A grammar particle indicating a space through or along which someone or something moves.
